data.title: 28 Unusual Things to do in New York 2024 ‚Äì Local Picks!
data.meta_description: Looking for some unique and unusual things to do in New York City? Let me be your local guide to some of the lesser known places in NYC!
data.text:
Being one of the biggest tourist destinations in the world, it‚Äôs easy to not want to see all of the major highlights when visiting New York City. I have lived in the area for over 15 years now. I‚Äôve learned a thing or two about what to see and do in this incredible city!

I‚Äôve found so many more adventurous and unusual things to do in New York. After seeing so many of the bigger bucket-list items, I realized there is so much more to explore in this incredible city!

New York City has so many extraordinary activities just waiting for you to explore and enjoy. From creative culinary experiences to thrilling outdoor adventures, this vibrant city has a never-ending supply of exciting and memorable opportunities. It‚Äôs simply impossible not to have fun while exploring.

In this post, we will discuss some of the most interesting and unique things NYC has to offer travelers and locals alike! Whatever your interests may be, there‚Äôs sure to be something that will pique your interests.

Unusual Things to do in New York

Go off the beaten path when visiting New York City. It‚Äôs easy to visit the most popular tourist destinations. The truly unique thing about this city is how much it has to offer.

üåüShort on time? Try this incredible tour by a local as our top pick for an unusual NYC activity!üåü

#1 Visit the High Line ‚Äì An Elevated Park Along a Former Railway Track

If you‚Äôre in New York City and looking for a unique outdoor experience, make sure to visit the High Line. This elevated park stretches above the bustling streets of Manhattan and offers stunning views of the city skyline.

The High Line was originally an old freight railway track, but has been transformed into a green oasis with grasses, wildflowers, and art installations. You can explore the park‚Äôs various sections, which range from intimate seating areas to open lawns perfect for picnics. It‚Äôs the perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of the city below.

Take a free tour of the park! Made available to the public on a first come first serve basis, tours are open year round typically operating on Tuesday evenings, Wednesday and Saturday mornings in the Spring, Summer and Fall. The operation on Wednesday and Saturdays only in the Winter. To attend a free tour by meeting at the Gansevoort Street entrance at the south end of the park.

Plan Your Visit: The High Line is open daily from 7am to 10pm.

#2 Take a Ferry Ride to Staten Island and Enjoy Unique Views of The NYC Skyline

If you‚Äôre looking for a different way to explore New York City, hop on a ferry to Staten Island! Not only is it a great way to escape the hustle and bustle of Manhattan, but you‚Äôll also be able to take in some stunning views of the city skyline.

As you make your way across the harbor, you‚Äôll see some of NYC‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, including the Empire State Building and the Statue of Liberty. And once you arrive in Staten Island, there are plenty of things to do and see, from checking out the local museums to grabbing a bite to eat at one of the many restaurants.

Things to know before you go:

The Staten Island Ferry is a free service that rides between the St. George Ferry Terminal in Staten Island and the Whitehall Ferry Terminal (also known as South Ferry) in Manhattan.

The Ferry runs 24 hours a day, 7 days a week varying between every 15 minutes to 30 minutes during slower times of day.

The best time to take a ride on the ferry is during off-peak hours (ie. not during rush hour where commuters are heading to and from work!)

#3 Participate in one of NYC‚Äôs many street festivals

If you‚Äôre looking for a fun way to spend a weekend day in New York City, why not check out one of the city‚Äôs many street festivals? From the colorful spectacle of the West Indian Day Parade to the delicious offerings at the Smorgasburg food festival, there truly is something for everyone.

Wander through the vibrant crowds, taking in the sights, sounds, and smells of the city as you sample unique street food, listen to live music, and maybe even pick up a one-of-a-kind piece of artwork.

Whether you‚Äôre a longtime resident or just visiting for the weekend, participating in a street festival is a great way to experience the energy and diversity of one of the world‚Äôs greatest cities.

#4 Explore City Island

Tucked away in the Bronx, New York, lies the charming oasis of City Island. With its quaint houses, small town feel, and waterfront view, it‚Äôs a hidden gem for both locals and tourists alike.

This tiny island packs a punch with its seafood restaurants, antique shops, and galleries. Perhaps the most well-known establishment is the Lobster Box‚Äîa favorite among seafood enthusiasts.

A day trip to City Island is the perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. So come and explore this seaside haven and indulge in its delightful offerings.

Getting to City Island and What to Expect:

By Train & Bus: Take the 6 train north to Pelham Bay Park and transfer to the #29 bus marked City Island. If driving to City Island, use GPS and type in ‚ÄúCity Island Avenue, zip-code 10464.‚Äù

#5 Ride the Tram to Roosevelt Island

If you haven‚Äôt ridden the tram over to Roosevelt Island yet, this will definitely need to be on your bucket list! This aerial tramway offers stunning views of the East River and the city skyline as you soar above the water. It‚Äôs a fun and affordable way to experience something a little off the beaten path.

Once you arrive on Roosevelt Island, there‚Äôs plenty to explore, including parks, historic landmarks, and great restaurants. Check out Four Freedoms Park or the historic Small Pox Hospital. When you are done checking out the sites, grab a meal at Nisi Kitchen or Granny Annie‚Äôs Bar and Kitchen.

Know Before You Go:

The Roosevelt Island Tram takes standard metro cards to ride. You must exit at each stop and pay to get back on (No staying on for a round trip ride). Note that strollers must be folded down to ride the tram.

Hours of Operation:

Sunday through Thursday: 6 AM ‚Äì 2 AM

Friday and Saturday: 6 AM ‚Äì 3:30 AM

Morning Rush Hours (Monday through Friday): 7 AM ‚Äì 10 AM

Evening Rush Hours (Monday through Friday): 3 PM ‚Äì 8 PM

#6 Take a Helicopter Ride over NYC

Want to see the best views of Manhattan and all of New York City? Try a helicopter ride. Seeing the iconic skyline from above is truly breathtaking and offers a perspective that can‚Äôt be replicated on the ground.

You‚Äôll get to soar past landmarks like the Empire State Building and the Statue of Liberty, and take in the vibrant energy of the city from a whole new angle.

Find the right tour company to get a knowledgeable and friendly guide that will point out interesting sights and provide interesting tidbits about the city‚Äôs history and culture. Don‚Äôt miss out on this unforgettable experience!

These tours can be expensive, but will offer some of the most incredible experiences out there!

üöÅ Check out this helicopter tour that offers a ride viewing all of the top sights in NYC!

#7 Visit Queens County Farm

Welcome to Queens County Farm, a charming destination that promises to take you back in time to experience the rural way of life. The farm spans over 47 acres of land and is recognized as the longest continuously farmed site in the State of New York.

As you walk through the gates, you‚Äôll be greeted with endless panoramic views of green pastures and farmland contributing to a distinct countryside ambiance. The farm offers a variety of engaging activities such as seasonal crop picking, visiting farm animals, and hayrides.

It‚Äôs a perfect place to experience authentic agricultural practices while having fun with your friends and family.

Admission to Queens County Farm is free to the public, but we highly recommend trying out one of their many festivals and events! These come at a small fee and are so much fun to enjoy. Events are offered all throughout the year.

While visiting, take a hay ride for $6 or feed some live stock. Make sure to read up on their rules, regarding feeding animals. Only certain items can be given. I would also make sure to check out the farm store and buying some fresh eggs before you go!

How to Get There:

Take the Q46, QM6, Q36 bus or drive using your GPS to 73-50 Little Neck Parkway. Floral Park, New York 11004-1129

#8 Ride the Seaglass Carousel

The magical sight of the Seaglass Carousel is a truly unique experience in NYC. A true work of art, the carousel features 30 massive fiberglass fish that spin and glide gracefully around and around. Hop inside a giant fish that is fitted with LED lights that change color as the carousel spins.

This one-of-a-kind ride takes you on a journey through an undersea world, surrounded by colorful fish overlooking the bay. Whether you‚Äôre visiting NYC for the first time or you‚Äôre a seasoned local, the Seaglass Carousel is a must-see attraction that promises to delight and captivate riders of all ages.

Know Before You Go:

Tickets are $5.50 and the carousel is open daily from 11am-7pm, Monday- Thursday and 11am-8pm on Friday ‚Äì Sunday *Weather permitting.

To get to the Seaglass Carousel by train, take the 1 train to South Ferry, R to Whitehall Street, W to Whitehall Street on weekdays. Or take the 4 or 5 train to Bowling Green. By bus take the M5, M15, M15, or M20 to South Ferry. If driving, set your GPS location to 17 State Street.

#9 Step Back Into The Middle Ages at Met Cloisters

I‚Äôm Sure you have heard of The Metropolitan Museum of Art or ‚ÄúThe MET,‚Äù but have you heard of Met Cloisters? Located in Upper Manhattan, the Met Cloisters is a museum dedicated to showcasing art and architecture of medieval Europe.

It is meant to be an extension of The MET, and you will find so much more beyond the galleries. Take a leisurely stroll through the gardens while marveling at the architecture and exhibits throughout the property.

Set high up in Fort Tyron Park, overlooking the Hudson River, this is truly a unique museum you will not want to miss.

Getting to The Met Cloisters

Take the A train to 190th Street then walk north along Margaret Corbin Drive for approximately 10 minutes If you are coming from The Met Fifth Avenue, take the M4 bus directly from Madison Avenue/83rd Street to the last stop. If driving, visitors can park in the free available parking in Fort Tryon Park.

Hours of Operation & Cost of Admission to Met Cloisters

Open Thursday‚ÄìTuesday: 10 am‚Äì5 pm. Closed Wednesday.

Tickets for general admission are $30 for adults; $22 for seniors; $17 for students. Children under 12 are free. Tickets include admission to both the MET and the Met Cloisters. Residents of NY, NJ, and CT Students can ‚Äúpay what the wish‚Äù to enter.

#10 Take a Tour of The Morgan Library & Museum

The Morgan Library was once the personal library of financier, collector, and cultural benefactor Pierpont Morgan. He had an extensive collection of rare books, manuscripts and old master drawings and paintings.

Eleven years after his death the library was donated to the public by his son J.P. Morgan. The library was eventually expanded to a museum while also adding a performance hall, caf√© and restaurant, a shop, reading room, and collections storage.

Whether you‚Äôre a book lover, history buff, art enthusiast, or just looking for something out of the ordinary, a tour of The Morgan Library is definitely worth adding to your itinerary.

Know Before You Go:

Hours of Operation: Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday, and Sunday from 10:30 am to 5 pm, and Friday from 10:30 am to 7 pm.

Ticket Prices: $22 for Adults, $14 for Seniors, $13 for Students with ID. Children ages 12 and under are free. Discounted tickets for anyone who is disabled is available for $13 and free of charge to their caregiver.

If you want to save money, try visiting on a Friday night. The museum offers free tickets between 5pm-7pm, reservation is required.

#11 Take a Secrets of Grand Central Tour

Grand Central Terminal is an iconic landmark that will most likely be on your bucket list. However, try taking a tour that uncovers secrets of this historic landmark. Go behind the scenes of one of the busiest train stations in the world to find hidden gems and secrets that most people never know about.

From historical tales and architectural marvels to secret rooms and hidden passageways, you‚Äôll learn everything there is to know about this iconic building. It‚Äôs a casual and informative experience that will leave you with a newfound appreciation for this remarkable feat of engineering and design.

üöÇ Try this guided walking tour to learn all about the hidden secrets in Grand Central Terminal!

#12 Tour the Brooklyn Museum and its World-Renowned Collections of Art

If you‚Äôre looking for a day filled with stunning artwork, the Brooklyn Museum is the place to be. Housed in a beautiful Beaux-Arts building, the museum boasts a collection that spans over 5,000 years of art from cultures all over the world.

From ancient Egyptian artifacts to contemporary paintings, you‚Äôll find something to marvel at around every corner. One standout exhibit is the American Art collection, which boasts works from big names such as Georgia O‚ÄôKeeffe and Winslow Homer. If you‚Äôre a fan of modern art, the museum‚Äôs contemporary collection is sure to captivate you.

Plan Your Visit:

The Museum is open Wednesday through Sunday, closed on Monday-Tuesdays. The hours are generally 11am-6pm except for the first Saturday of the month where the hours are 5pm-11pm.

Admission is $16 for Adults, $10 for students with ID, visitors with disabilities and Adults 65+. Under age 19 enter for free.

#13 Check Out NY Transit Museum

If you‚Äôre a transportation enthusiast or a history buff, you won‚Äôt want to miss out on the NY Transit Museum. Located in Brooklyn, this fascinating museum offers visitors the chance to explore over 100 years of New York‚Äôs public transportation history.

Set in an actual subway station from 1936 in Brooklyn, NY You‚Äôll get to see and climb aboard vintage subway cars, trolleys, and buses. The museum also features exhibits on the evolution of fare collection, the construction of the subway system, and the impact of public transportation on New York City‚Äôs growth and development.

Know before you go!

The museum is located in a historic underground subway station. There is an accessible entrance, however this is not equipped to handle strollers. You must carry your stroller down the stairs (So pack a light one!!)

There is no cell phone service in the museum, so keep a close eye on your party so that you don‚Äôt get separated.

Hours are Thursday ‚Äì Sunday, 10am to 4pm, closed Monday ‚Äì Wednesday.

General admission for adults is $10, Seniors and Children $5.

#14 Visit Color Factory

The Color Factory is an interactive exhibition that is bursting with vibrant hues and playful installations that will transport you to a world of pure joy. From rainbow colored rooms to a gold disco dance, there are so many things to explore.

This unique museum was created with the help from artists all over the world. As you go through the museum, each room has its own special exhibit. Every one of your senses will take part when you are here!

The price on this museum can seem high, but there is a lot included. The best part is all of the fun photo ops that are included in your package! Each room has cameras placed throughout and you are free to take as many pictures as you‚Äôd like.

The digital downloads sent directly to your email once you are finished! There are also fun surprises and treats sprinkled throughout!

Know Before You Go:

Tickets must be purchased in advance, as they do not sell tickets at the location. If you are heading there in colder weather, jackets can be checked at no additional cost as well! Remember to wear comfortable (and colorful!) clothes.

How to get there: Take the C or E train to Spring Street station or the 1 train to Houston Street, Canal Street stations.

#15 Visit Museum of Ice Cream

The Museum of Ice Cream is unlike any other, with rooms dedicated to everything from a sprinkle pool (yes, you can jump in!) to a bananas-themed room. Not to mention the unlimited ice cream treats along the way! This is makes for the perfect stop when visiting NYC with kids or even a group of girlfriends!

Whether you‚Äôre a kid at heart or just looking for a fun and unique date idea, a trip to the Museum of Ice Cream is sure to satisfy your sweet tooth and leave you with some Insta-worthy snaps.

Know Before You Go:

Hours are 11am-7pm on weekdays (Closed on Tuesdays) and 10am-8pm on weekends. Tickets purchased before noon will get you discounted pricing! Prices will vary but start at $25 and kids under the age of 2 are free.

To get there, take the R or W train to Prince Street or take the 6 train to Spring Street.

#16 Visit Museum of Sex

The Museum of Sex might not be at the top of your list of tourist destinations in New York City, but perhaps it should be. Tucked away in the heart of Manhattan, this museum is anything but ordinary.

It‚Äôs an intriguing and highly informative exploration of the history and evolution of human sexuality through the lens of art, science, and technology. It‚Äôs the perfect place for both couples and adventurous singles looking to learn more about themselves and each other.

From exhibitions on erotic art, sex toys, and kinky fashion, to interactive installations on human sexuality, this museum promises to be a highly entertaining and thought-provoking experience.

Know Before You Go:

The museum is open daily on weekdays from 1pm-10pm and weekends from 12pm-12am. Ticket prices start at $36 for general admission and go up from there.

To get there: Take the 6 train to 28th street and walk east to 5th ave. Address is 233 5th Ave. New York, NY

#17 Watch Shakespeare in the Park

Every summer, the Public Theater puts on free productions of Shakespeare‚Äôs plays in Central Park. It‚Äôs the perfect opportunity to enjoy theater in a beautiful outdoor setting while also soaking up some culture.

Even if you are not a Shakespeare expert, the performances are often reimagined in modern settings, making them accessible and enjoyable for all. This years performance is Hamlet, happening at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park West.

How to Get Tickets and What to Expect

Option 1: Wait in line at the theater. Tickets are offered on a first come first served basis starting around 12pm day of the show. You will need to arrive early and wait for a long time. Bring a chair and some snacks for the day!

Option 2: Sign up for the digital lottery through Todaytix. Sign up is offered between midnight and noon and selected at random.

Option 3: In person lottery at the downtown Public Theater. Signup at 11am and the drawing will take place at noon.

Option 4: Outer Boroughs tickets. Location and dates will vary, but tickets will often be available between 12pm and 2pm at different locations outside of Manhattan. Check Public Website for updated information on locations and dates

Option 5: Standby line. Starting around 6pm the day of the show you can line up at the standup line for unclaimed tickets. There is no guarantee, but hopefully you could get lucky!

Option 6: Make a donation of $300+ for a guaranteed reserved seat! This is the easiest way to see a show, but comes at a price tag. If this is on your bucket list and you have the funds, go for this option to guarantee your spot!

Last but not least, make sure you are registered for a Public Theater ID. This is required for all ticket options!

#18 Get involved with an Immersive Theater Show

Why sit and watch a show when you can become part of it? One of the most unique experiences in New York City is catching an immersive theater performance.

These shows are unlike anything you‚Äôve experienced before. You‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre part of the story as you move through different rooms, interact with actors, and even participate in the action. It‚Äôs a unique way to engage with theater and get fully immersed in the performance.

Check Out These Shows for an Incredible Time!

Sleep No More is the original immersive theater show of NYC. Set in the McKittrick Hotel on West 27th St. you will move freely from room to room as you watch scenes from Shakespeare‚Äôs Macbeth.

See The Great Gatsby at The Mansion Park Avenue Hotel. Spend your evening dancing and drinking with characters from the show while watching their incredible performances.

#19 Take a Manhattan Architecture Cruise

One incredible way to see the New York City skyline is on a cruise. This Manhattan Architecture Cruise will not only show you the stunning skyline views from a unique perspective, but you‚Äôll also learn about the city‚Äôs rich architectural history.

From iconic buildings like the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building to hidden gems nestled along the waterfront, this cruise has it all. Sit back and relax as your guide fills you in on the stories and secrets behind each architectural masterpiece.

üö§ Click Here to take the Manhattan Architecture Cruise üèô

#20 Check Out The Bushwick Collective and Take Graffiti Lessons in Brooklyn

Graffiti in New York City dates back to the 1960‚Äôs. While it is still a crime, there are plenty of legal places for artists to express themselves. The Brooklyn Collective is a place where local artists are featured among the street walls.

One unique activity to try in NYC is your very own graffiti lesson. Learn the basics of spray painting and have the opportunity to develop your own unique style.

Classes are available for all skill levels, so whether you‚Äôre a complete beginner or a seasoned artist, you‚Äôll have the chance to hone your skills. Plus, the vibrant backdrop of Brooklyn‚Äôs urban landscape provides the perfect inspiration for your artistic endeavors.

üé® Sign up for Brooklyn Graffiti Lessons today and start expressing yourself through the dynamic medium of street art.

#21 Take a Harlem Hip Hop Walking Tour

If you‚Äôre a fan of hip hop and want to delve deeper into its roots, you should definitely take a Harlem Hip Hop Walking Tour. This tour is a great way to explore the streets of Harlem and learn about the neighborhood‚Äôs rich history in the world of hip hop.

You‚Äôll walk in the footsteps of legends like Biggie Smalls, Tupac, and Jay Z, and see some of the most important sites in the history of the genre. From the Apollo Theater to the Graffiti Hall of Fame, you‚Äôll get a true hands-on experience of hip hop‚Äôs early days, and gain an appreciation for how this genre of music has evolved over time.

üéº Book This Harlem Hip Hop Walking Tour For a Unique NYC Experience!

#22 Try a private tour with a local for hidden gems

Who knows a destination better than the local residents? Guided tours with locals can make a trip more exciting and enriching. They provide an insider‚Äôs view of the culture and history while taking away the chore of planning the itinerary.

Many tourists restrict themselves to tourist spots, missing out on hidden gems like locals‚Äô favorite food joints, unique markets, or stunning viewpoints with stories attached to them. Private tours with locals can be customized according to the interests of the tourists for a more personalized experience.

üåüCheck out this tour for a unique and unusual view of NYC!

Unusual Restaurants and Bars in NYC

#23 Have a Drink at the oldest bar in NYC

For a truly unique experience, take a step back into history and have a drink at the oldest tavern in New York City, Fraunces Tavern. Take a step back in history and stand where George Washington stood when he thanked our troops for their service after defeating the British Army.

Established in 1762, Fraunces Tavern served as a meeting spot for early revolutionaries and many of our founding fathers. Today, you can visit Fraunces Tavern to have a meal, have a drink, or head upstairs to the Fraunces Tavern Museum and explore a piece of history.

Location and Hours of Operation:

Open daily from 11am- midnight+. Located at 54 Pearl Street. New York, NY 10004

#24 Eat or Drink at a Hidden Speakeasy

If you haven‚Äôt been to a hidden Speakeasy restaurant or bar yet, then this is absolutely something you will want to try! The first time I visited Beauty and Essex with some friends from work, I was enthralled with excitement of the location and the experience.

Beauty and Essex is located in what looks like a small pawn shop in the lower east side of Manhattan. However, through some secret doors you are taken into an incredible restaurant hidden in plain sight!

To find these unique establishments, you‚Äôll need to do some research and possibly even a little bit of searching to find them, but thankfully for you, I‚Äôve rounded up a few of my favorite places in New York City.

The Best Speakeasy Restaurants to Try in New York City

Beauty and Essex

Jewel Thief

Bathtub Gin

Unusual Shopping Experiences in NYC

#25 Check out some of the best thrift stores in the country

Looking to score some fabulous finds without breaking the bank? New York City has some of the best thrift store shopping there is! You can discover amazing deals on clothing, furniture, and more. There are countless hidden gems waiting to be uncovered.

AuH2O is located in the East Village and you will find a mix of vintage clothing and accessories. They offer affordable prices with racks at the $5 and $10 price range. You can also shop via their instagram where they drop items and you can comment or DM to purchase and have delivered.

Awoke Vintage is located in Brooklyn and has three locations, Williamsburg and two in Greenpoint. You can also shop their Instagram store for pickup or delivery.

Tokio7 is located on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and is one of the largest thrift stores in the city. They offer mens and womens vintage designer clothes and accessories.

#26 Shop at Brooklyn Superhero Supply Store

Brooklyn Superhero Supply Store is not your typical store. From capes to secret identity kits, this store has everything a superhero might need. The best part? You don‚Äôt need to have any superpowers to shop here.

It‚Äôs the perfect place to find unique gifts for any superhero lover in your life. The sell fun things like super powers in a can. Everything from super powers of gratitude, intelligence, immortality and more. Proceeds for the super power cans go to the 826NYC program. This program for young kids and school programs where they offer writing workshops.

How to Get There:

Take the F, G, or R train to the 4th Avenue-9th Street Stop to address: 372 Fifth Avenue (btw. 5th and 6th Street) in Park Slope.

Hours of Operation: Tuesday ‚Äì Sunday 12:00pm-5:00pm

#27 Shop at Tannen‚Äôs Magic Shop

For a truly unique shopping experience check out Tannen‚Äôs Magic Shop. This iconic store has been around since 1925 and is the oldest magic shop in America. It has a wide selection of magic tricks, props, and accessories for both beginners and experienced magicians.

Along with their extensive inventory, Tannen‚Äôs also offers lectures and private lessons to help hone your skills and learn new tricks. Whether you‚Äôre looking to impress your friends or take your magic career to the next level, Tannen‚Äôs Magic Shop is the place to go.

Location: 45 W 34 St, Suite# 608, New York, NY 10001. The shop is located right near Macy‚Äôs in Herald Square, easiest trains will be B, D, F, M, N, Q, R, W at Herald Square stop.

Hours of Operation: Monday ‚Äì Friday 11am ‚Äì 6pm. Saturday 10am-4pm. Sunday, closed

#28 Check Out The Evolution Store

Looking for something out of the ordinary? The Evolution Store is a unique shop and a treasure trove of fascinating specimens, from taxidermy creatures to stunning mineral formations.

You‚Äôll find everything from skulls to seashells, and each item is carefully preserved and presented for maximum impact. Whether you‚Äôre a collector, a nature lover, or just someone who appreciates the beauty of the natural world, The Evolution Store is a must-visit destination.

Open daily from 11am-8pm

Located at 687 Broadway, New York, NY 10012. To get there take the M1 or M55 bus to Broadway/W 3 St. Closest train would be the 6 train to Bleeker St.

Unusual Places to Stay in NYC

Staypinapple is a fun hotel that is decked out in the cutest decor! This hotel prides itself on its uniqueness and not so standard amenities. Rather than a continental breakfast they offer popcorn and cookies. They charge a single amenities fee that covers everything from the internet, unlimited bottled water, bikes to take out and about and so much more.

The Beekman, A Thompson Hotel is located in lower Manhattan. The style and decor of this hotel is what sets it apart. Not your typical modern, cold rooms and lobby, but so many unique details and pops of color make this hotel truly special.

The proximity to downtown Manhattan and the Brooklyn Bridge makes this hotel even better. Keep in mind that the rooms are a bit on the smaller side, but decorated so nice you won‚Äôt even notice!

Untitled at Freeman Alley is located in lower Manhattan which makes for an excellent location for all things downtown and Brooklyn. The hotel is located in Freeman Alley and has a unique style that is a mix of modern art and contemporary design.

While you are there be sure to check out the famous Freeman Alley and the art murals surrounding the entrance way. Then grab brunch at the Freeman for a delicious meal and incredible bloodymary!

Final Thoughts: Unusual Things to do in New York

New York City is an amazing place, filled with endless possibilities and unique experiences. From the awe-inspiring must-sees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Empire State Building to the offbeat museums, shops, and tours ‚Äì NYC truly has something for everyone.

Whether you are into art, history, shopping or just exploring new places ‚Äì this incredible city has got you covered. No matter how long you stay in NYC, it‚Äôs sure to be a memorable trip that you‚Äôll never forget.
